title: How to Cut Kale

steps.headline: Clean the kale as soon as you can.
steps.description: If you don't clean the kale straight away after you get home from the store or after you pull it from your garden, you run the risk of damaging the leaves. Over time, the dirt will wear away the leaves and ruin them.

steps.headline: Pour cool water into a large bowl.
steps.description: You can use either tap water or distilled water to fill the bowl. Make sure the bowl is large enough to fit all the kale you want to clean. If you have loads of kale to clean, clean different batches at a time. The deeper the bowl is, the easier it will be for you to clean the kale.

steps.headline: Wrap a rubber band around the kale and place it in the bowl.
steps.description: Grab a bunch of kale with your hand. Place the rubber band around the bunch to keep it all together while you prepare it. The rubber band should be tight enough to keep the bundle together but not so tight that it damages the leaves. If you need to, twist the rubber band around and place it over the kale again to bind it tightly together.

steps.headline: Swish the bunch of kale around in the bowl of water for 3 minutes.
steps.description: Submerge the kale in the water and gently move it side to side in the bowl. This gentle back and forth motion will remove some of the dirt and debris from the leaves. You can also gently rub the leaves with your fingers to scrape away excess dirt. Make sure you're not too rough as you'll damage the kale.

steps.headline: Leave the kale in the bowl for 5 to 10 minutes before swishing it again.
steps.description: When you're finished swishing the kale, don't take it out of the bowl. Leaving it in the bowl will soften the leaves and remove most of the dirt and debris over the 5 to 10 minutes. After the time is up, gently swish the kale around in the bowl again for 3 minutes or so.

steps.headline: Rinse the kale under cold water and empty the bowl.
steps.description: If there are any leftover leaves in the bowl, take them out and place them to the side. Give these leaves a quick rinse as well. Pour the water from the bowl down the drain. Hold the kale under the cold water and rotate it so the water cleans it evenly.

steps.headline: Place the bunch of kale on paper towels to dry.
steps.description: Once the swishing and rinsing are finished, lay some paper towels out on a clean, dry work surface. Let the kale dry on the paper towels for 1 hour or so. If you don't have enough time to let the kale dry for an hour, gently pat it dry with paper towels. Remove the rubber band and separate the leaves if you want them to dry faster.

steps.headline: Remove the stem from the kale.
steps.description: Grab the end of the stem tightly with your thumb and index finger on 1 hand. Using the other hand, grab the point on the stem just below where the leaves begin. Pull back with the hand holding the end of the stem, letting the stem slide through your index finger and thumb on your other hand. The leaves should slide off the stem as you pull it through your fingers. It doesn't matter what you use your dominant hand and non-dominant hand for. Discard the stems when you've removed them from the kale.

steps.headline: Place 3 to 4 kale leaves on top of each other and roll them up.
steps.description: Lay the kale leaves flat on your work surface. Try to lay them uniformly on top of each other. Grab 1 side of the pile and roll the kale up tightly. For curly kale, it might be easier to tear it up into small pieces before rolling it up and slicing it.

steps.headline: Slice the pile into 1 in (2.5 cm) thin strips.
steps.description: Grab the pile with 1 hand and use a sharp kitchen knife to slice through the kale. You might need to use some pressure to slice through the pile if the leaves are strong. Use any hand you feel comfortable with for either job. Use a chopping motion to slice the kale. Don't try to tear it apart with the knife.

steps.headline: Cut the kale into smaller pieces if you want to.
steps.description: It depends on what meal you're making, but sometimes it's better to cut the kale into smaller sections. Simply stack the slices on top of each other and cut them into smaller sections.

steps.headline: Put your chopped leaves into a bowl and use the kale in your next meal.
steps.description: If you want to make kale salad, simply add your favorite dressing or sauce to the bowl and eat it. You can also add tofu, cheddar, or apples to the bowl to complete your kale salad.

steps.headline: Place whole kale leaves in the fridge before you cut them so they stay fresh.
steps.description: Do this if you want to store the kale in the fridge for a few days before you cut it. Place the bunches of kale (leaves and stems) in paper towels and put the towels into resealable plastic bags. Put the bags in the fridge when you're ready. The kale should keep for about 1 week. Kale that's spoiled will feel soggy and won't smell fresh.

steps.headline: Store cut kale in the fridge for up to 5 days.
steps.description: If you want to use the kale in another meal or keep it for leftovers, wrap the leaves in paper towels. Place the paper towels into a resealable plastic bag and put the bag in the refrigerator. After 5 days, you'll have to throw the kale out.

steps.headline: Blanch the kale and put it in the freezer to store it for up to 8 months.
steps.description: Boil a large pot of salted water. When the water reaches a boil, place the kale leaves into the pot. Leave the kale in the pot for about 2 minutes until it becomes brighter in color. Place the kale in a bowl of ice water to stop the cooking process after removing it from the pot. Leave it in the ice water for around 1 minute. Pat the kale dry, then lay the leaves out on dry paper towels. Put the paper towels into resealable plastic bags and place the bags in your freezer. To thaw, place the kale in a colander and rinse it with cool water until it's defrosted.
